question.name: Evaluate the importance of the Proclamation to the progress of the War and to later generations in the U.S.
question.questiontext: Evaluate the importance of the Proclamation to the progress of the War and to later generations in the U.S.

question.name: Quest1
question.questiontext: You have just read a historical account of how Lincoln came to issue the Emancipation Proclamation. Here are some reasonable questions you might ask that differ in cognitive level. Put them in order from lower-order to higher-order questions

question.name: When did Lincoln issue the Proclamation, and how many years was it after the start of the Civil War?
question.questiontext: When did Lincoln issue the Proclamation, and how many years was it after the start of the Civil War?

question.name: c. The Proclamation did not free all slaves. What were its limitations?
question.questiontext: The Proclamation did not free all slaves. What were its limitations?

question.name: d. What events in the War led Lincoln to issue the Proclamation at the particular time?
question.questiontext: What events in the War led Lincoln to issue the Proclamation at the particular time?

question.name: Which KWL Steps Activitate Prior Knowledge
question.questiontext: A critical aspect of learning is activating prior knowledge about a topic in order to make connections to new information. Which step or steps in the KWL strategy encourage students to activate prior knowledge?

multichoice.correctfeedback: Both the K and the W help activate prior knowledge. K asks directly what the learners already know. W requires activation of prior knowledge to ask meaningful questions.
multichoice.partiallycorrectfeedback: Both the K and the W help activate prior knowledge. K asks directly what the learners already know. W requires activation of prior knowledge to ask meaningful questions.
multichoice.incorrectfeedback: Both the K and the W help activate prior knowledge. K asks directly what the learners already know. W requires activation of prior knowledge to ask meaningful questions.

question.name: Which of the following strategies are included in Reciprocal Teaching
question.questiontext: Which of the following strategies are included in Reciprocal Teaching?

answer.answertext: Asking what one already knows about a topic
Asking for clarification of words and concepts

multichoice.correctfeedback:
Correct.

The following strategies are included in Reciprocal Teaching:

  • Asking main idea questions,
  • Making predictions,
  • Summarizing, and
  • Asking for clarification of words and concepts
multichoice.partiallycorrectfeedback:
The following strategies are included in Reciprocal Teaching:

  • Asking main idea questions,
  • Making predictions,
  • Summarizing, and
  • Asking for clarification of words and concepts
multichoice.incorrectfeedback:
The following strategies are included in Reciprocal Teaching:

  • Asking main idea questions,
  • Making predictions,
  • Summarizing, and
  • Asking for clarification of words and concepts

question.name: Match the group of sample questions to the question type
question.questiontext: Match the group of sample questions to the question type

match.questiontext:
Can you explain what you have done so far? What else is there to do?

Why did you decide to use this method?

Can you think of a more efficient strategy?

Why did you decide to organize your results like that?

How do you think this would work with other numbers?

What do you notice when….?

Is that true for all cases? Explain.

How would you prove that?

Can you think of a counter example?

What do you need to find out?

What strategies are you going to use?

What information do you have?

Will a calculator help? How?

What tools will you need?

What do you think the answer or result will be?

What do you think about what … said?

Do you agree or disagree? Why or why not?

Does anyone have the same answer but a different way to explain it?

Can you convince the rest of us that your answer makes sense?
match.answertext: Questions to help students collectively make sense of mathematics

match.questiontext:
How did you get your answer?

What if you could only use…?

Does your answer seem reasonable? Why or why not?

Can you describe your method to us all? Can you explain why it works?

What have you learned or found out today?

What are the key points or big ideas in this lesson?

What if you had started with…rather than …?

question.name: Which verbs when used in a question elicit higher level thinking?
question.questiontext: Which verbs when used in a question elicit higher level thinking?
question.generalfeedback:
In addition to those shown as correct, other verbs that elicit higher level thinking when used for questioning include: 

  • contrast
  • describe
  • differentiate
  • predict

question.name: Question STem Matching with Bloom
question.questiontext: Match each question stem (on the left) from Reciprocal Peer Teaching with the appropriate level (on the right) from Bloom’s taxonomy. (Note: You will not use all levels of Bloom’s taxonomy.)

matchoptions.correctfeedback:
Correct.

 

Reciprocal Peer Teaching Bloom's Taxonomy  
What is the main idea of _____?

Understand

 
What are the strengths and weaknesses of _____?

valuate
What is a new example of _____?

Apply
What is the best _____ and why?

Evaluate
What conclusions can I draw about _____?

Analyze
What is the difference between _____ and _____?

Analyze
How would I use _____ to _____?

Apply
Explain why _____ .

Analyze

question.name: Questions Readers Should Ask Themselves
question.questiontext: The KWL and Reciprocal Peer Questioning strategies are most useful for informational and persuasive texts. What are three of the questions that readers should ask themselves when reading literary texts?
question.generalfeedback:
Questions readers should ask themselves when reading literary texts include:

  • Who is the main character?
  • Why did the character do that?
  • What is the main problem?
  • How does the character attempt to solve the problem?
  • How is the problem resolved?

If the three questions you identified included any of the above or were similar to them, then you answered the question correctly.

In general readers of literary texts, using the KWL strategy, should ask questions that about what they know, want to know, and have learned from the reading as well as higher-order open-ended questions using the Reciprocal Peer Questioning Strategies.

answer.answertext: Why did the character do that?
How does the character attempt to solve the problem?

question.name: What are some of the benefits to students when they develop their self-questioning, self- monitoring and reflection skills?
question.questiontext: What are some of the benefits to students when they develop their self-questioning, self- monitoring and reflection skills?
question.generalfeedback:
Benefits to student development of self-questioning, self-monitoring, and reflection skills include:

  • Enhanced ability to discover effective strategies;
  • Enhanced ability to change course when problems arise;
  • Improved discourse among learners and between learners and instructors;
  • Improved performance on tasks

question.name: Reciprocal Peer Questioning and Reciprocal Teaching
question.questiontext: How are Reciprocal Peer Questioning (RPQ) and Reciprocal Teaching (RT) similar? How are they different? Identify at least one similarity and at least one difference.
question.generalfeedback:
The following are similarities between Reciprocal Peer Questioning and Reciprocal Teaching:

  • Questioning,
  • Peer interaction and regular turns,
  • Teachers model and guide questioning.  

The following are differences between Reciprocal Peer Questioning and Reciprocal Teaching: 

  • RT includes 4 strategies,
  • RPQ uses question frames to prompt complex questions while RT just asks for main idea questions (and clarifying questions),
  • RPQ usually involves pairs while RT usually involves small groups.

You may have listed other similarities and differences.  Revisit the video for a review on how RPQ and RT compare.

question.name: Question the Author
question.questiontext: In Question the Author (QtA), students learn to ask questions of the author. How is this different from just asking questions about the text?
question.generalfeedback:
There are many possible answers to this question.  Correct responses include:

  • QtA prompts critical thinking about the author’s perspective.
  • QtA promotes understanding that authors may be indirect (e.g., they may imply a character’s motivation).
  • QtA encourages students to think about the author’s craft, which they may use in their own writing.
  • QtA lets students know that problems with comprehension may be partly the fault of the author.

Review TEAL Center Fact Sheet No. 12 on Deeper Learning through Questioning for more information about Question the Author.

question.name: Self-Questioning and Monitoring Comprehension
question.questiontext: How does self-questioning support the important metacognitive process of monitoring one’s comprehension?
question.generalfeedback: Your response to this question should've explained that self-questioning supports monitoring one's comprehension because when you ask yourself a question about a reading passage and cannot answer it, you know that you need to re-read the text or do something to understand the text better.

question.name: Questions Readers Should Ask When Reading Literary Texts
question.questiontext: The KWL and Reciprocal Peer Questioning strategies are most useful for informational and persuasive texts. What are three of the questions that readers should ask themselves when reading literary texts?
question.generalfeedback:
Questions readers should ask themselves when reading literary texts include:

  • Who is the main character?
  • Why did the character do that?
  • What is the main problem?
  • How does the character attempt to solve the problem?
  • How is the problem resolved?

If the three questions you identified included any of the above or were similar to them, then you answered the question correctly.

In general readers of literary texts, using the KWL strategy, should ask questions that about what they know, want to know, and have learned from the reading as well as higher-order open-ended questions using the Reciprocal Peer Questioning Strategies.

question.name: How can instructors help students monitor their own thinking and problem solving processes?
question.questiontext:
“Students learn mathematics and solve problems better when they monitor their thinking and problem-solving steps as they solve problems.  Monitoring and reflecting during problem solving helps students think about what they are doing and why they are doing it, evaluate the steps they are taking to solve the problem, and connect new concepts to what they already know. The more students reflect on their problem-solving processes, the better their mathematical reasoning—and their ability to apply this reasoning to new situations—will be.”

The above quote is from Improving Mathematical Problem Solving in Grades 4 through 8: A Practice Guide.  How can instructors help students monitor their own thinking and problem solving processes?
question.generalfeedback:
Instructors can help students moniotor their own thinking and problem solving processes if they:

  • Provide students with prompts or questioning sequences
  • Model thinking out loud
  • Ask students to explain their problem solving processes to the class
  • Encourage students to ask each other questions

question.name: What should you keep in mind when planning your lessons?
question.questiontext: What should you keep in mind when planning your lessons?

answer.answertext: Allow about 75% of class time for completing worksheets.
Focus primarily on questions that have one correct answer.
Pose questions that actually need to be answered.
Incorporate verbs in your questions that elicit thinking in the higher levels of Bloom’s Taxonomy.
Provide wait time to allow students to respond.
